Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2012 04:16PM jcb51 wrote: Hi, Carol. I'm just guessing here about the dosage, but unless a doctor would give a much-reduced dose, no chemo treatment is considered as palliative. Usually when a cancer patient goes to palliative care, they are not given chemotherapy of any kind. I have bone and lung mets and have been battling fluid build-up from pleural effusions in both lungs for the past year. This past Monday I started my third round of GemZar (gemcitabine). In August I had a pleural catheter placed in my right lung so I could drain the fluid myself. Within a little over a month, the fluid in my right lung dried up and no new fluid came into my lung. I had the catheter removed and had one placed in my left lung. Now I'm no longer able to get any fluid when I try to drain it and will have it removed soon. No new fluid is coming into either lung. GemZar is the only treatment I've received, so it has to be responsible for the fluid stopping. My latest tumor marker test went up 2 pts. My onc said a rise of only 2 pts is considered stable. The previous tumor marker test came down from 209 to 164. I will be getting scanned after completing this round (3 treatments). I have only taken one other chemo (Navelbine) since my stage iv diagnosis. It worked to some degree for a while and then stopped so I was switched to GemZar. I am not getting palliative care and my onc is using GemZar in hopes of killing my cancer, not just keeping me stable.  What may have you confused is the fact that GemZar (as well as Navelbine) is among the chemo drugs that have milder side effects than some of the others. I haven't lost my hair and have not had serious problems with nausea, skin problems, and the other SE's that some of the harsher chemo drugs cause. My counts, however, dropped on both drugs. Navelbine took my WBC's way down. GemZar caused my WBC's and platelets to drop slightly and my RBC's dropped so low that I had to be given a drug to help rebuild my them.  Both drugs also caused fatigue. Many members have had very good results with GemZar and have had very little trouble with side effects. Maybe they will post their experiences with it. I hope GemZar works well for you. Jan

Posts.Content: jcb51 wrote: Got the results of my lung CT today and it shows that my cancer is stable! The pleural effusions that made my life miserable for many months are gone. Most of the skin mets on my chest are gone and the bigger ones on my left shoulder have shrunk significantly. The bone lesions that showed on the lung CT are also stable. When my skin mets started shrinking, my breathing also improved. I've been on oxygen 24/7 for about a year and now I'm able to go for long periods without my oxygen when I'm sitting. I can even go without my 02 when I get up and move around if I'm not on my feet too long. I still need it if I'm walking or standing for longer periods of time. My onc can hear air moving all over my lungs. He said he thought the chronic fluid build-up prevented my muscles from fully expanding. Now I can breathe much deeper. Halaven really knocks my WBC's & RBC's out, but I've been getting regular shots of Neulasta and Aranesp to boost my counts which really make a difference. I had problems with fatigue in the beginning, but that has greatly eased up. I take it two wks on and one wk off. Some weeks I'll feel tired for a day or two and other weeks I don't have any SE's at all. It hasn't affected my taste like Navelbine and Gemzar did. Food tastes good again, so my appetite is much better. Overall I feel much stronger and I'm even gaining a little weight! Faslodex didn't work at all for me. Navelbine & Gemzar worked for a short period of time and then stopped working. I can't help but worry the same thing will happen with Halaven, but I've had such dramatic results and I feel so much better. Maybe I've finally found the chemo that will keep that Stable Boy around for a while! Jan Diagnosis 12/2001: IDC, 3.9 cm, Stage IIB, 0/8 nodes, ER+, PR+, HER2-. Bone and lung mets discovered 1/13/12. Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2012 09:40PM jcb51 wrote: Ann, thank you for bringing attention to us stage iv gals who are often forgotten.  Too many "survivors" (myself included) have a false sense of security after passing the 5-yr mark and assume they are cured. Here are some stats that show the recurrence rate nearly doubles between 5 and 10 years. I found that rather shocking and I'm sure your readers would too. "Roughly 20 percent of breast cancer survivors who have finished five years of additional cancer treatment after their initial therapy will have a recurrence within 10 years of their treatment, according to the American Cancer Society (ACS). Overall, 11 percent of women will suffer a recurrence at five years and 20 percent at 10 years, the ACS says." http://www.livestrong.com/article/55159-statistics-breast-cancer-recurrence/ Jan

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2012 02:06PM jcb51 wrote: Ann, you should get an ER or doctor ASAP. I've gone septic once with peritonitis from my Crohn's Disease and twice from chemo tx during my original cancer treatment 10 yrs ago, so I know first-hand how serioius it is. I was in the hospital when I developed peritonitis and went septic, otherwise I probably wouldn't have survived it. With my first chemo tx, my onc didn't prepare me well enough for what to watch for and I let a fever go for several days before I called him. By that time I was in really bad shape -- out of my head, didn't know where I was or who my husband was. Was in the hospital for nearly a week. I also had a close friend whose 6-yr-old daughter died from sepsis when she came down with chicken pox right after having the flu. Even when I wasn't taking chemo, every time I've gotten cellulitis in my lymphedema arm, my dr went into a panic and tried to hospitalize me because he was so afraid I'll go septic. All three times that I was septic, they put me on IV antibiotics. Sepsis can progress very fast and is very serious...and it's even more dangerous for you because of the c-diff. Please get some help before it gets more serious. Jan

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2013 10:36AM jcb51 wrote: I started Havalen Dec 19th. I take it for two weeks on and one week off. Just finished my 3rd cycle. During first cycle my skin mets showed significant shrinkage and my breathing greatly improved. During the 2nd cycle I started feeling so much better overall and ever since I have felt better than I have in many months. This is by far the most tolerable chemo I've taken. No nausea issues, no increased neuropathy and no distorted taste which makes eating a pleasant experience again. Last month's TM's went down only 3 pts, but stable is good. I have a lung CT scheduled for Feb 19th to see how well it's working on my lungs. I had more problems with fatigue during my first cycle. That has eased up with each cycle. My biggest problem is the impact it has on my blood counts. So far it hasn't attacked my platelets, but it hits my RBC's and WBC's pretty hard. I get booster shots for both (Anaresp for RBC's & Neulasta for WBC's) which really help. Previously I was on Navelbine and then Gemzar. Both worked for a month or so and then quit. My onc told me 49% lose their hair on Halaven. So far I've been one of the lucky ones. My hair had thinned quite a bit on Navelbine and Gemzar, but has started to grow back in on the Halaven. I hope Halaven works well for all of you.:) Jan

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2013 12:31PM jcb51 wrote: Halaven has been such an easy chemo for me until my last two treatments. During some of them I couldn't even tell I had taken anything. That changed after the treatment I received on Feb 27 (treatment 2 of round 5). Within 8 hrs after I got the treatment I started feeling bad. I've never had a chemo treatment hit me that quickly. I was extremely tired, weak and wobbly on my feet. This lasted all week. The following week was my "rest week" so I didn't have a treatment. I went in on March 13 for treatment 1 of round 6 fully expecting at least one of my counts to be too low to get the treatment, but instead my counts were pretty good, so I got it. My hemoglobin was still low (9.4) but was higher than it's been in a while. Apparently I'm experiencing cumulative fatigue. I haven't felt any worse since getting the last treatment, but I'm still very tired. My latest tumor markers were 186 (down 24 points from 210), so it's still working. It's disappointing, tho, to go from feeling so good to being so fatigued. Jan

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2013 12:55AM jcb51 wrote: My skin mets started a little over a year ago. Mine are raised round bumps that feel hard. I don't know if it's a coincidence, but the first ones popped up on my left shoulder after my first Faslodex treatment. From Feb 2012 until Aug 2012 I had five bumps that formed a circle. One of them was biopsied and was positive for breast cancer. For several months they had no discoloration. After several months they began to turn a little darker than the surrounding skin with a bit of a reddish cast to them. Faslodex didn't work for me, so I was switched to Navelbine which worked for a while and then quit. I started Gemzar next and after my first treatment, I broke out in a rash on my left chest (original cancer was in left breast) of the same type raised bumps. They have not been biopsied, but onc says they are skin mets. After Gemzar quit working I started Halavan in Dec 2012. After I finished the first cycle, the skin mets started shrinking. Most of the bumps on my chest have completely flattened and the ones on my shoulder (which were a lot larger than those on my chest) have shrunk considerably. My onc was amazed. Neither of the other two chemo drugs had any affect on my skin mets, but the Halavan definitely shrunk them. The bumps on my chest never did change color, but they were only there for about 4 months. Last month I had a lung CT which showed my lung mets are now stable as are the bone mets that are visible in the lung CT. Lynne, have you asked your onc about radiating your rash? Radiation was recommended by my onc when I just had the skin mets on my shoulder. My shoulder was radiated in 2002 when I had my original breast cancer and radiating an area that has already been radiated can cause problems, so I didn't look into having any more radiation. MzMerz, at times mine itch and sting a little bit. Jan

Posts.Content: May 26, 2013 03:31AM jcb51 wrote: Your wife is very lucky to have you doing such a great job with her insurance and disability claims. I went on SS disability in 1987 for Crohn's disease. It took me two years to get approved and they gave me backpay for the entire two years. None of it was taxable. Depending on your state tax rules, you may have to pay state taxes, but unless they have changed the federal rules, you won't have to pay federal taxes on it. The life insurance policy I had thru my employer was automatically accelerated when my SS disability was approved. I can't remember for sure, but I believe I only had to pay state taxes on it. I don't know how old your wife is, but even though she didn't check the box for STD or LTD on her pension, if she has ten years or more in her pension plan, she will be able to freeze her pension until she reaches the age limit required by her pension plan. Jan

Even while wearing oxygen, on any kind of exertion I'm back to having some degree of SOB and fast heartbeat. Sometimes it's pretty severe and my heart races as high as 144. None of the dr's I've asked have been able to give me a clear answer. I'm currently on chemo break and it will be 2 wks Mon since my last Gemzar tx and the fatigue the chemo had been causing has just about completely gone away. Last hemoglobin (a wk ago) was 9.4 which isn't too bad.  I had several good days earlier this week and then last night and today my SOB has been pretty bad. Several drs seem to think I have lung damage either from one of the chemo drugs I've taken in the past or the Gemzar I'm taking now. Since this has been a problem for several months, I tend to think it's not being caused by the Gemzar, although it may be making it worse. Has anyone else had SOB with low 02 sats as well as rapid heartbeat? If so, which do you think starts the problem -- SOB/low 02 or rapid heartbeat? Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2012 06:01PM jcb51 wrote: Thanks for your replies. After all the comments about how exercise can actually make you feel better when you feel tired, I decided to try to push myself a little more. My activity level isn't nearly as high as most of yours. Because of the SOB I get on just about any kind of activity, I have to pace myself and make sure my oxygen hasn't dropped too much. Yesterday I went downstairs to our basement and did a couple of loads of laundry and changed the sheets on our bed. I went up and down the stairs about 4 times. Today my husband and I went grocery shopping. I have to use a motorized cart at Kroger because of my SOB and my husband follows me with a regular cart. We were in the store for about an hour. Even though I'm not walking, I'm up and down quite a bit, reaching for things off the shelves, getting into areas the cart won't access, etc., and usually I'm pretty tired if we shop for very long. After we got home I put the groceries away and did a little cleaning in the kitchen. After I rested for a while, I swept my kitchen floor. I had to pace myself and sit down and rest a couple of times because of SOB. After I finished, I felt a little tired, but not too bad. I rested for a little bit and decided to mop my floor which really needed it. I was only able to do the kitchen half of it before I pooped out and I had to stop and rest several times. My kitchen/dining room area is fairly large.  After I finished I was tired, but it was a "good" tired, not a "wiped out" or "fatigue" tired. I never thought I could feel good about mopping a floor! LOL This may not seem like much, but the chemo has caused me to be so fatigued that I haven't been able to do much at all for several weeks and to me it was quite an accomplishment. I'm going to continue to push myself a little more each day and hopefully be able to get some strength/stamina built up. I thought resting when I felt fatigued was what I needed, but I'm convinced now that I was just making it worse. Thanks for helping me realize that. Jan

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2012 07:17PM jcb51 wrote: Fitz and HLB, after reading your posts I googled Patrick Quillen and found his website. He has some very good info posted there and offers a lot of free info about his diet and other things. Apparently he was the head of the Cancer Treatment Center's of America's nutrition dept. for a few years. There are a couple of things he stresses that I've found to be wrong. First, he says cancer needs sugar to thrive and that if we cut out all sugar we will help kill our cancers (not true). Also, he says cancer cells are anaerobic (do not need oxygen to survive/cannot surive without oxygen).  He states that deep breathing adds oxygen to our blood that can keep cancer cells from thriving. This is also not true. Cancer cells can and do thrive in any amount of oxygen. They can adapt to grow in very small amounts of oxygen, but they do need a certain amount of oxygen. The information he offers on nutrition is well worth taking the time to read, though. I've never seen an author who offered so much free info about his book. Most of them throw you a crumb or two and make you buy the book to get more info. His book is still available on both Amazon and Ebay and I will probably buy a copy to get all of his info on nutrition and also his recipes. Here is a link to the nutrition area of his website: http://www.patrickquillin.com/nutritioncancer.html Thanks for posting the info on the book. Jan

Posts.Content: May 18, 2012 09:51PM jcb51 wrote: Ann, I was diagnosed with Crohn's Disease when I was 23. When I was 34, after being off work for 6 mos with a really bad flare-up, my dr suggested that I file for SS disability.  I was turned down (as are most people) and had to go through their appeal process. My appeal was also turned down. This was in 1985, so SS rules and procedures may have changed since then, but at that time the final appeal was a hearing. I hired an atty who specialized in SS to handle my appeal hearing and I was approved. I worked for the Teamsters union at the time and was able to receive a cash settlement for my life insurance and another one for a pension plan. I also received a monthly disability pension benefit. Since all three were disability options under my insurance and pension plans, none of them affected my SS payments. You can only qualify for the benefits you mentioned if you are sick, so they will not affect your SS. Your insurance benefits should not be taxable. If you qualify for a disability pension, it's taxable only if your employer paid 100% of the premiums. Someone mentioned unemployment benefits. In order to apply for unemployment benefits, you have to be physically able to work. Unless  their rules have changed, in order to apply for SS disability, you must claim that you are unable to work for 12 months or longer (that's the way my application read in 1985 anyway), so I don't see how you could file applications for both. If you are turned down for SS, you should definitely find an atty who specializes in SS. My atty told me that SS has certain symptoms for each disease/condition that you must have in order to be approved and the attys know what questions to ask your dr in order to get you approved. My uncle had stage IV lung cancer and his disability was approved the first go-round. I've always heard that people with stage IV cancer are always approved, so hopefully you won't have to worry about the appeals process. You should also get in touch with your union rep to see what benefits are available to you. Your union membership may have benefits that the person you talked to in your office may not be aware of. Be sure to check your pension plan to see if there is a disability benefit. Many pension plans have a disability benefit based on your years of service. Best of luck to you. Jan

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2012 09:13PM jcb51 wrote: HLB, cancer cells DO need sugar to thrive, but depleting sugar from our diet will not deprive cancer cells of the sugar they need or keep them from growing. Here is some info from the Mayo Clinic that someone posted for me in another thread about sugar and cancer: Cancer causes: Popular myths about the causes of cancer Myth: People with cancer shouldn't eat sugar, since it can cause cancer to grow faster. Fact: Sugar doesn't make cancer grow faster. All cells, including cancer cells, depend on blood sugar (glucose) for energy. But giving more sugar to cancer cells doesn't speed their growth. Likewise, depriving cancer cells of sugar doesn't slow their growth. http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/cancer-causes/CA00085/NSECTIONGROUP=2 Cancer cells will get the sugar they need one way or another. If they don't get enough sugar from our diets, they will cause our bodies to break down stored body fat to produce the sugar they need. Jan

Posts.Content: jcb51 wrote: Before I was dx'd stage iv, I struggled with my weight for years, losing and gaining the same 10-20 lbs over and over. I had four sets of clothes (esp jeans) -- can't-wear-it-yet-but-maybe-someday (skinny size 10 or smaller), satisfied-with-my-weight-but-would-love-to-lose-a-little-more (size 10 with thighs & hips relaxed), not-really-happy-but-I-can-live-with-it (size 12), OMG!-gotta-lose-10lbs! (size 14). I love to buy from ebay because I can find really unique things at great prices. Through the yrs I've accumulated several things that were smaller than described and I couldn't wear them. Some I gave to friends or donated to the Salvation Army, but I kept the ones I really liked and put them with my skinny size 10 clothes. Unless I was in my skinny size 10 clothes, I rarely weighed myself because it was too depressing. Instead I used my current clothing size to gauge my eating habits. I had not weighed myself in well over a year. I first started having symptoms last Aug with shoulder pain. Figured I had just sprained something so I wasn't concerned. Within several wks I developed what I thought was a chest cold/bronchitis and the shoulder pain got worse. Saw my family dr who ran shoulder and chest xrays which showed nothing. He thought my shoulder might just be arthritis and prescribed an antibiotic for my bronchitis. Was ecstatic to find I had lost 20 lbs even though I hadn't been dieting. I told DH that I was going to watch what I ate and try to lose a little more and dreamed about getting into my skinny clothes! My symptoms continued to get worse and I also began to feel more and more fatigued. Went back to dr and got another antibiotic which also didn't help much. Finally in December he ordered scans because of my past history of bc and discovered my mets. During the 5 mos when my dr was trying to figure out what was wrong, I lost about 30 lbs. I FINALLY could fit into clothing I had not worn in years -- probably even some of my "skinniest". Trouble was I felt too bad to dig them out or to go anywhere to wear them! I saw an onc from IU Medical Center who started me on Faslodex. By the time he figured out it wasn't working, I had developed bilateral pleural effusions and he said I needed to immediately start chemo. He prescribed Navelbine which worked for a while and then stopped. By this time I had lost another 20 lbs. Now I'm on GemZar which seems to be working. No new fluid has been forming in my pleural effusions for several wks and GemZar is the only new tx I've had. I noticed today that a lymph node which was slightly enlarged has also shrunk. :) Had a bit of a setback with a nicked lung during thoracentesis in mid-Aug which took a major toll on me, but I continue to improve and feel stronger every day. I had a PleurX catheter placed in my rt lung following the nicked lung and already (a month later) the fluid seems to be almost gone, so I may be able to have the catheter removed soon. As for my weight, after my 5-day hospitalization from the nicked lung and the toll all of the procedures I had took on me, I'm down to 92 lbs. And all those cute, "skinny" clothes I have been anxiously waiting to fit into? Well, the time I could wear them has come and gone and I missed it! Now most of them are too big! I haven't given up on them yet, though! So far, GemZar has not affected my taste like Navelbine did, so food tastes good to me again. Now that I'm feeling better, I need to concentrate on building up the amount I'm able to eat at a time and finding high-cal foods that taste good to me. Not sure what I believe anymore, but if there is a God, he definitely has a sense of humor. It may seem weird, but little things like this that I can laugh about make the rest of it just a little more bearable. :) Jan Diagnosis 12/2001: IDC, 3.9 cm, Stage IIB, 0/8 nodes, ER+, PR+, HER2-. Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2012 11:09PM - edited Dec 14, 2012 11:10PM by jcb51 Hi, soleil. I've been on oxygen 24/7 for about 9 months. I have interstitial lung damage which is not reversible, so I will always be on oxygen. If you're sure it's okay to wean yourself from the 02, be cautious and wean yourself in baby steps. Monitor your 02 sats carefully. I was told that when your oxygen drops to 88 or lower you are straining your heart which can cause congestive heart failure. I have a 50-ft hose on my 02 tank which gives me more distance with my 02. With the long hose I can go downstairs and do a load of laundry, go into any room in our house and even sit in our porch swing on the back porch. Sometimes I don't want to drag the hose around, though, and I just take my 02 off to go to the bathroom, get something to drink from kitchen, etc. If you take short walks around the house, make sure you stay close to your oxygen cannula. I've experienced the sheer panic of not being able to get my breath, so I never get far from my cannula. When I go out for long periods of time with my portable tank, I've been experimenting with using the 1-liter setting instead of using the 2-liter setting that I normally use. If I'm not moving around a lot, I get along fine. It makes my oxygen last longer and gives me a little more freedom. Jan

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2013 09:57AM jcb51 wrote: Raro, I've been on Halaven since Dec 19th with a few breaks. In the beginning it was very easy...some weeks I couldn't even tell I had taken anything. Then after I had been on it for a while, it started hitting my blood counts really hard. Several times I couldn't get a treatment because one of my counts would be too low or I was just too weak to get it. I've had to get IV iron twice and a transfusion once. Most of the time I've had to take Anaresp to boost my RBC's and Neulasta to boost my WBC's which help keep my counts from getting too low. Even with all the problems, it has been much easier for me than Navelbine or Gemzar and it's kept my bone & lung mets stable since Feb. I have a little nausea from time to time but meds take care of it. I've been on a break for the past 5 wks...originally because I had picked up a bug. Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2012 07:48PM jcb51 wrote: Hi, Annie. This past Wed I had the catheter removed from my right lung and had one placed in my left lung. The catheter tube is small and is coiled beneath a 4x4 and then a clear bandage is placed over the 4x4. Unless you would wear something really tight, it doesn't not show through your clothing. It won't be a problem on a job at all. I have a PleurX brand, but there is one called Aspira that might be a little better than the PleurX. It uses gravity to drain instead of the vaccuum system that PleurX uses. I had planned on getting an Aspira, but my need for one came up suddenly when I had a pneumothorax, so I went with the PleurX. I get along good with the PleurX, but if I drain the fluid too quickly or drain too much at a time, I get some pleurisy-type pain that can last several hours. It's my understanding that you don't have this problem with the Aspira. Below is the url of a board search I did for the Aspira catheter that will give you more info about it. You will also find info if you google it. http://community.breastcancer.org/posts/search?search_builder%5Bkeyword%5D=aspira&search_builder%5Bauthor%5D=&search_builder%5Bsource%5D=&search_builder%5Bdate_range%5D=&commit=Search If you have any problems with the url, click on the blue "search" button on the left side near the top of this page. Enter Aspira in the Keyword box and click "search". I hope you're feeling better. Jan

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2012 04:48PM jcb51 wrote: I started out on 40 mg of Navelbine. After just two treatments my WBC dropped, so my onc cut the dosage of my third treatment to 20 mg. and also gave me a shot of Neuprogen. The next week (4th treatment) my WBC's were up a little, but not enough and my RBC's were also down, so he gave me 25 mg. Last week my WBC's were up a little more, but still low and my RBC's went down a little more. He gave me 25 mg. He also started me on Xgeva for my bone mets. Next week I get a break and will not get a Navelbine treatment. Then we'll resume with the 25 mg dosage. Navelbine appears to be working for me. This week a chest xray showed that the mets in my lung have not produced any more fluid. The pleural effusion in my right lung is gone and there is just a little bit of fluid remaining in my left lung. Onc is checking tumor markers in 2 wks and will repeat scans in early June. The main problem I have with Navelbine is fatigue and it is horrible. I'm able to do very little. When I shop I have to go to Kroger or Walmart where they have the motorized scooters and afterwards I am worn out. I have very little appetite and I know I'm not eating enough which adds to the problem. I'm not losing any more weight, but I'm not gaining. I've lost over 40 lbs since Oct when my lung symptoms started. Since the Navelbine seems to be working, I will continue with the lower dose and see if the fatigue improves. If it doesn't, I will have a serious talk with the onc because my current QOL is not good enough. Jan

Posts.Content: jcb51 wrote: After I completed 5 cycles (10 tx's) of Halaven (thought it was 6 cycles as I posted earlier, but somehow I miscounted), scans showed my lungs and bones were stable. My last 3 tx's caused horrible fatigue which got increasingly worse. Earlier tx's had been a breeze, but onc said my fatigue was caused by the cumulative effect of the chemo. During the 4 wks I went with no tx, my TM's jumped from 186 to 246 -- up 60 pts! I don't notice any changes in my lungs and bones, but my skin mets have progressed. In fact, they were progressing at the time I got the scans that showed my bones and lungs were stable. I'm wondering/hoping the rise in TM is just from skin mets and that my bones and lungs are still stable, but won't know until new scans. If not, I'm thinking my cancer must be pretty aggressive to cause TM's to rise that much in just 4 wks' time...and that is terrifying. Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2012 04:46PM jcb51 wrote: Hi, Annie. I'm sorry you're having to go through this. I discovered I was stage iv last January. They found bone and lung mets plus a few small lesions on my liver that so far they believe are cysts and not mets. They started me out on Faslodex which didn't work. Within a month after I had developed large bilateral pleural effusions which I had drained several times in Feb and March. Both were malignant. They started me on Navelbine which apparently worked for a while. I stopped getting new fluid in my lungs and didn't have to have them drained from March 'til late August. Navelbine is a fairly easy chemo for most. Most don't lose their hair. The worse side effect is fatigue. When they decided Navelbine had stopped working for me, they switched me to GemZar (another easy one). I just completed one 3-treatment cycle and haven't had any scans or tumor markers yet. Fluid has again stopped going to my lung, though, and nothing but the GemZar has changed. I had a PleurX catheter put in my right lung in August. I was no longer able to drain any fluid from it, so today they took it out and put a catheter in my left lung. My surgeon got 1000 ml of fluid out of it right after he put it in and I don't think he drained all that was there. I think they're only supposed to drain 1000 ml max at one time. So far I haven't had any problems with pericardial effusion. My onc told me Navelbine is a little better for lung mets than GemZar, so if you have a choice, I would push for Navelbine. Best of luck to you. Jan

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2012 08:21AM jcb51 wrote: I studied nursing and we had several lab sessions where the instructor used bodies to demonstrate how various systems in the body worked. Before we started she told the class how much the university appreciated the fact that these people had donated their bodies and that they were to be treated with the utmost respect. She said anyone who made a disrespectful remark about the bodies would be immediately expelled. I am thinking about donating my body to Indiana University, but I'm still a little undecided. If I knew my body would be used for research, I would definitely do it. I did a little checking online and this is what I've found: Some of their donated bodies are used for research, but most are used for education. If they are used in undergraduate classes, only the instructor handles the body and uses it for demonstration to classes (like the ones they used in my nursing classes). If they are used by medical school students, the students dissect them and they are used over two semesters. They return the cremated remains to the family within 18-24 months. They pay for all of the expenses, including the cremation, and assist in filing of the paperwork (death certificate, obituaries, and other necessary forms) at no cost. The bodies are embalmed, but to protect the humans who will be exposed to them, the embalming process is different (a "lighter" version). Other universities may handle their donations differently. You should be able to find info by googling "donate body to" and add the university. I haven't checked, but research hospitals may have different guidelines. I did not want to be embalmed, so that kind of bothers me. I need to find out more about their embalming process before I decide. Before my bc dx I had signed up to be an organ donor, too. It really bothers me that I can no longer donate my organs. Jan

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2012 11:58PM jcb51 wrote: Ann, I'm sorry you're having to go thru this again. I lost my hair the first time three wks after my first chemo treatment. It was the dead of winter and cold, so I wore mostly winter hats. I also had a wig but it was really hot and itchy, so the hats were more comfortable. Six months later after my mastectomy, my onc put me on taxotere and told me my hair would fall out again. My hair had come back in salt and pepper. For some reason, only the dark hair fell out, leaving me with thin gray hair, but I still had hair. My onc couldn't believe that it didn't all come out. When it came back in, it was all gray.  If I were you, I wouldn't shave your head just yet. It could be that all of your hair won't fall out. Even if it's too thin to go without a wig or your halo, having even a thin layer of hair underneath should make it more comfortable. I have a small head, too, so I can relate to your "pinhead" description. When I was bald I looked like the little old man from the old Benny Hill shows. One night I was sitting at my computer. About 5 feet directly in front of me was a window. I had had the window opened earlier, so the blind was raised. Suddenly I looked at the window and saw what appeared to be an old man peering in the window at me. I jumped back and started to scream for my husband. Then I realized it wasn't an old man...it was ME!!! If I would lose my hair again, I would try one of the halos, too. Most of the heat and itching from my wig was right at the top. I have a headband with bangs attached that I used to wear under caps and hats. Let us know how you like your halo when you get it.  Jan

I was on Navelbine for several months and the biggest problem I had with it was the horrible fatigue. I was three wks on and one wk off and by the end of the third wk I could barely move I was so tired. It stopped working for me so I take GemZar now. So far it's much easier. When I was taking tamoxaphen 10 yrs ago, Vitamin E capsules helped my hot flashes. My oncologist also gave me Prozac because anti-depressants are supposed to help with hot flashes. I didn't like the way the Prozac made me feel, though, so I quit taking it. I didn't realize until later that the feelings I was having that I didn't like (feeling like an emotional zombie) were actually caused by the tamoxaphen. Hope you get good results on your scan and that things get better for you soon. Feel free to throw as many pity parties as you need. We'll be here for you.:) Jan
